case_vignette: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of a pruritic skin rash on his chest. His mother says that he has no history of dermatological problems. He was born at term and has been healthy except for recurrent episodes of otitis media. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 102/62 mm Hg. Examination shows vesicles and flaccid bullae with thin brown crusts on the chest. Lateral traction of the surrounding skin leads to sloughing. Examination of the oral mucosa shows no abnormalities. Complete blood count is within the reference range.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

I've got an itchy skin rash on my chest.
What is the age and sex of the patient?
The patient is a 3-year-old boy.

trial_2.summarized_conversation: A 3-year-old boy presents to the clinic with an itchy skin rash on his chest. There are blisters and flaccid bullae with thin brown crusts present on the chest.
trial_2.vignette_frq: Bullous impetigo caused by Staphylococcus aureus.
trial_2.singleturn_mcq:
Final Diagnosis: Dermatitis herpetiformis (if gluten intolerance is also present)
Stevens-Johnson syndrome and Bullous impetigo typically present with other symptoms such as fever, mucosal involvement, and large blisters respectively. Atopic dermatitis usually affects the face, hands, and behind the knees, and it is a chronic condition with a history of eczema. Dermatitis herpetiformis, however, is a type of gluten-sensitive enteropathy that often presents with an itchy, vesicular rash on the elbows, knees, buttocks, and back. If the patient has a history of celiac disease or gluten intolerance, this diagnosis is more likely.
trial_2.summarized_mcq: The most likely diagnosis is Bullous impetigo.
